results.title: The Global warming. Parts 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: Mark Redhead, Jean-Marc Seban, London Weekend Television and Vision Group
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Climate & man”.
Global Warming and the Greenhouse Effect are no longer unknown scientific concepts. They affect all people on the globe, and the prevention of further deterioration of the environment and atmosphere are critical issues facing governments. This comprehensive examination of the the causes and implications of greenhouse and global warming also looks at possible strategies which will in time slow down the devastation caused by these phenomena.

results.title: Classic Looney Tunes Cartoons
results.brief_description: Released as a 50th birthday tribute to Bugs Bunny, this series of videos are collections of classic Warner Bros. cartoons of all your favourite characters, from Daffy Duck to Porky Pig. Sit back and enjoy the fun-filled animation that is instantly recognisable and famous world-wide.

results.title: Romance and reality; Man the measure of all things
results.creator_credit: Ann Turner, Michael Gill, Peter Montagnon and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode numbers 3 and 4 of Series “Civilisation”.
Part 3: “Romance and reality” - Sir Kenneth journeys from a castle in the Loire, through the hill towns of Tuscany and Umbria to the cathedral baptistery at Pisa as he explores the aspirations and achievements of the later Middle Ages in France and Italy. Part 4. “Man the Measure of all Things” - Sir Kenneth visits Florence where European thought was first given a new impetus by the rediscovery of the classical past. He then continues his journey to the palaces of Urbino and Mantua, centres of Renaissance civilisation.

results.title: The Worship of nature; The Fallacies of hope; Heroic materialism
results.creator_credit: Peter Montagnon, Michael Gill and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode numbers 11, 12 and 13 of Series “Civilisation”.
Part 11. Christianity was the chief creative force in Western civilisation until about 1730, when it became eclipsed by the worship of nature. Part 12. The French Revolution led, not to freedom, but to terror, the dictatorship of Napoleon and the bureaucracies of the 19th century. Part 13. The final program shows how the heroic materialism of the past hundred years has been linked with an equally remarkable increase in humanitarianism.

results.title: The Skin of our teeth; The Great thaw
results.creator_credit: Michael Gill, Peter Montagnon and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode numbers 1 and 2 of Series “Civilisation”.
Part one. Sir Kenneth Clark looks at the Dark Ages and unravels the extraordinary story of how European thought and art were saved by “the skin of our teeth”, travelling from Byzantine Ravenna to the Celtic Hebrides, from the Norway of the Vikings, to Charlemagne’s chapel at Aachen. Part two. Traces the sudden re-awakening of European civilisation from the first manifestations at the Abbey of Cluny in France to its high point, the building of the Chartres cathedral.

results.title: Civilisation
results.creator_credit: Peter Montagnon, Michael Gill and BBC
results.brief_description: In this groundbreaking television series of thirteen programs, Sir Kenneth Clark presented his personal evaluation of the history and civilisation of Europe from the Dark Ages to the dawning of the 20th century.
results.description: In this groundbreaking television series of thirteen programs, Sir Kenneth Clark presented his personal evaluation of the history and civilisation of Europe from the Dark Ages to the dawning of the 20th century.

results.title: The Pursuit of happiness; The Smile of reason
results.creator_credit: Michael Gill, Peter Montagnon and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode numbers 9 and 10 of Series “Civilisation”.
Part 9. Sir Kenneth Clark reflects on the nature of 18th century music, from Bach to Mozart and on the architecture of that period. Part 10. Looks at the sensible, sophisticated men and women who met in the salons of 18th century Paris and became the precursors of revolutionary politics.

results.title: Grandeur and obedience; The Light of experience
results.creator_credit: Peter Montagnon, Michael Gill and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode numbers 7 and 8 of Series “Civilisation”.
Part 7. Sir Kenneth Clarke presents Rome of the Counter-revolution - the Rome of Michelangelo and of Bernini. The Catholic Church in its fight against the Protestant North developed a new splendour symbolised by the glory of St. Peter’s. Part 8. The telescope and the microscope revealed new worlds in space and in a drop of water. The realism of Dutch painting took the observation of human character a stage further.

results.title: The Hero as an artist; Protest and communication
results.creator_credit: Peter Montagnon, Michael Gill and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode numbers 5 and 6 of Series “Civilisation”.
Part 5. Michelangelo, Raphael and Leonardo da Vinci are featured in this program which centres on Papal Rome in the early 16th century. Sir Kenneth Clarke’s theme takes him through the gardens and courtyards of the Vatican to the rooms decorated for the Pope by Raphael and to the Sistine Chapel. Part 6. The theme of protest and communication leads Sir Kenneth to the Reformation, the Germany of Albrecht Durer and Martin Luther, to Erasmus, the France of Montaigne and to the Elizabethan England of Shakespeare.
